FLUOCINOLONE ACETONIDE

CORTICOSTEROIDS (TOPICAL)

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • National funding/access decisions
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Unlicensed use
  • Prescribing and dispensing
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Treatment of visual impairment associated with chronic diabetic macular oedema which is insufficiently responsive to available therapies (specialist use only),

By intravitreal injection

  • For adults
    190 micrograms, to be administered into the affected eye.

Severe inflammatory skin disorders such as eczemas, Psoriasis,

To the skin

  • For adults
    Apply 1–2 times a day, to be applied thinly, reduce strength as condition responds.
  • For children 1–17 years
    Apply 1–2 times a day, to be applied thinly, reduce strength as condition responds.

Potency of preperations

Fluocinolone acetonide 0.025% cream, gel, and ointment: potent.

Fluocinolone acetonide 0.00625% cream and ointment: moderate.

Fluocinolone acetonide 0.0025% cream: mild.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With intravitreal use in adults

Manufacturer advises avoid unless potential benefit outweighs risk—no information available.

Contra indications

Known side effects

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: blurred vision in adults, cataract in adults, conjunctival haemorrhage in adults, glaucoma in adults, ocular discomfort in adults, raised intra-ocular pressure in adults, reduced visual acuity in adults, vitreous floaters in adults, vitreous haemorrhage in adults,

uncommon: conjunctival ulcer in adults, endophthalmitis in adults, eye discharge in adults, eye pruritus in adults, headache in adults, iris adhesions in adults, iris neovascularisation in adults, maculopathy in adults, ocular hyperaemia in adults, optic atrophy in adults, optic nerve disorder in adults, posterior capsule opacification in adults, retinal exudates in adults, retinal vascular occlusion in adults, sclera thinning in adults, vitreous degeneration in adults, vitreous detachment in adults,

Directions for administration

With intravitreal use in adults

Concurrent administration to both eyes not recommended. For further information on administration and repeat dosing, consult product literature.

Advice for patients and carers

With topical use

Patient counselling is advised for fluocinolone acetonide cream, gel and ointment (application).

National funding/access decisions

NICE TA301

With intravitreal use in adults

Fluocinolone acetonide intravitreal implant for treating chronic diabetic macular oedema after an inadequate response to prior therapy (November 2013)

Fluocinolone acetonide intravitreal implant is recommended as an option for treating chronic diabetic macular oedema that is insufficiently responsive to available therapies only if:

  • the implant is to be used in an eye with an intra-ocular (pseudophakic lens) and
  • the manufacturer provides fluocinolone acetonide intravitreal implant with the discount agreed in the patient access scheme.
www.nice.org.uk/TA301 www.nice.org.uk/TA301

Cautions regarding administration

  • With intravitreal use: raised baseline intra-ocular pressure in adults

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

With intravitreal use in adults

Monitor for raised intra-ocular pressure (particularly if raised at baseline), retinal detachment, endophthalmitis, vitreous haemorrhage or detachment within 2–7 days following the procedure.

Monitor intra-ocular pressure at least every 3 months thereafter (for approximately 36 months).

Unlicensed use

With topical use in children

Not licensed for use in children under 1 year.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Gel is useful for application to the scalp and other hairy areas.

Prepared medicinal forms of FLUOCINOLONE ACETONIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Cream
Ointment
Gel
Implant
